STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 6, 2023
Jennifer Milliman
Fostering Futures
2008 Hogback Rd., STE 6
Ann Arbor, MI 48105-9751
RE: License #: CB810302599
2008 Hogback Rd., STE 6
Ann Arbor, MI 48105-9751
Dear Ms. Milliman:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on December
19, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (734) 395 – 0920.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
brownp2@michigan.gov
(248) 860-3012
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents,
as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every
90 calendar days thereafter.
One of 25 updated services plans were reviewed, the report dated 12/27/21 –
3/26/22 submitted on 3/27/22 was one late 1 day.
REPEAT VIOLA TION FROM RENEWAL 2021
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please
note that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not
be included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722 - 08C Required Participation in Development -Foster Parent
Caregiver.
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including those of
parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor, foster parent,
caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Four of 24 service plans reviewed did not show documentation of
compliance related to the policy’s 30-day foster parent, youth’s signature
requirement.
• One youth updated service plan dated 11/2721 – 2/24/22, the PATP was
signed on 4/6/22 by the foster parent.
• One youth initial service plan dated 12/1/21 – 12/26/21, the PATP was
signed by the foster parent on 2/8/22.
• Same youth updated service plan dated 3/27/22 – 6/24/22, the PATP was
signed by the foster parents on 8/25/22 and 9/7/22.
• One youth updated service plan dated 3/3/22 – 5/31/22, the PATP was
signed by the foster parent on 7/21/22.
3

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
No Technical Assistance provided.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
No Consultation provided.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a corrective action plan for the renewal inspection dated
10/4/2021 and the corrective action plan was accepted on 10/25/2021. The agency
was in noncompliance with rules 400.12312, Foster parent training, 400.12418,
Development of service plan and DHHS Policy 722.6B, Family team meeting.
The agency made progress with its corrective action plan. It was not completely
successful with all aspects of the plan, as indicated by the repeat citation reported in
this report. The agency reports their employees work diligently, and they continue
their efforts to improve compliances.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS:
There were two safety alerts.
Concern:
There is a bedroom in the basement that’s equipped with a set of bunk beds. The
room does not have a means of egress. A safety ladder is also recommended for
their second story bedrooms.
Resolution:
The agency licensing worker spoke with the foster parent over the phone on
10/11/22. The foster parent agreed to only use the room in the basement as
storage. The Licensing worker asked the foster parent to resign the agency
basement
safety plan. The safety plan and pictures of the before and after is attached to the
4

of safety alert.
Concern:
The foster parents refused to comply with a home visit, therefore safety of the home
and child (ren) could not be verified. A safety alert was submitted with a request for
the agency to verify safety of the children and the home. Current photos of the
children were requested with the resolved alert.
Resolution:
Worker completed the home visit with the foster parents on 9/23/2022 at
12:45pm. The foster parent returned the children home early from day care. Upon
arrival, the children were eating lunch in their chairs and the foster parents reported
the children are doing well. The youth talked about their daycare, said they have a lot
fun, and talked about one of their friends. The foster parents have also arranged for
speech therapy for the children to begin within the month. Both children sat next to
the worker on the couch after finishing their lunch and showed their shoes and
named some colors. Both children were missing nap time, so they were a little tired.
No concerns were observed. The children are very comfortable with both foster
parents. Photos was taken of the children. The home is appropriate for the
children and there were no safety concerns observed. They had adequate child
proofing, such as locks and gates on stairs. The foster home is in a residential
neighborhood. The children have their room upstairs, and each have their own
bed. They have highchairs in the living room where they eat some meals.
Refer to the safety alert for photos
Chief Administrator Assessment:
The CAA was reviewed and discussed onsite. The Chief Administrator reported that
she and the program manager have met and summarized the primary barriers to
addressing and fixing non-compliances. She said there was more remote working,
turnover, increased expectations and little time to chase down MIA parents, given all
the documentation requirements. She said they incorporated several things,
including making all caseworkers be in the office at least 12 hours a week to make
sure they keep up with printing, scanning, uploading. They enlarged their leadership
team to create more support for the front-line workers. She said they have added a
position that includes community management which addresses staff morale and
involves check-ins with newer staff and staff issues, so in addition to their supervisor
they have another person to vent to express issues or just get support.
Interviews:
Program manager, licensing worker and foster care worker were interviewed onsite.
The staff reported that the agency has been steady but not as busy as before
COVID. They all love working for the agency and would not change much. One staff
added it would be great to get more support for the case aids to make them feel
more appreciated due to their job requirements of always transporting. Another staff
reported it would be great to increase staff diversity.
5

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, we recommend that the facility
continue on a regular license.
02/02/2023
______________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
02/06/2023
